states.2: short and tuberous, with sheathing leaves crowded in dense rosettes

states.1: suberect, and rooting directly at the base only
states.2: creeping, and rooting directly at intervals along their length
states.3: creeping, and rooting from characteristic, leafless, root-bearing branches (rhizophores)

states.2: ostensibly monopodial vegetatively owing to unequal development from the original dichotomies

states.1: dorsiventrally organized, with four ranks of leaves

with anomalous secondary thickening via a cambium external to the primary phloem, producing small quantities of vascular tissue centripetally, and generating centrifugally large quantities of so-called prismatic tissue, comprising a mixture of xylem, phloem and parenchyma

7.description: The old leaf bases in Isoetes, persistence

states.1: persistent on the stem, short and blackish, each with two long points
of two kinds: those of the two ranks on the upper side of the stem appressed and directed towards the stem apex, and those of the two lower ranks larger and spreading laterally

states.2: differing markedly from the foliage leaves

states.1: aggregated into well defined terminal cones
states.2: in fertile zones tending to alternate with sterile zones along the stems, rather than in well defined terminal cones

states.1: sessile at the tips of the normal shoots
states.2: on long, erect peduncles which bear distant, appressed, scale-like leaves

states.1: basal and subsessile on the adaxial surfaces of the sporophylls, non-septate
states.2: very large, transversely and longitudinally septate and embedded in the leaf bases

18.description: The megaspores of Isoetes, surface ornamentation

states.3: with a reticulate ornamentation, neither tuberculate nor spiny
